_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: 1. Overfill alarms  2.  Physical inspections (SPCC monthly, Daily SWPPP)
_prev_prog_3.CT_OtherType: Plant Technician Competency Matrix (evaluation by Shift Supervisors and Plant Manager
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Distillation Deluge - FM Global inspection and test
_prev_prog_3.Description: The process includes one above ground Denaturant storage tank (T-805, 120,000 gallon capacity).  No denatured Ethanol is stored on-site.  All denaturant blending happens in an inline blending process that occurs at the truck and railcar loadouts.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Missouri Ethanol (POET Biorefining - Laddonia) produces fuel grade ethanol from corn-based feedstock, via fermentation and distillation.  The primary operations that are carried out at the facility are receiving, raw material storage, blending/fermentation/distillation, addition of denaturant, inventory storage, shipping and administration.  The [dry] feedstock is stored, milled and conveyed from the Grains Building to the Process Building, where it is mixed to form a mash and fermented.  The resulting liquor is distilled and processed to produce denatured ethanol, that is shipped via truck or rail car.



The materials at the plant that are regulated under the RMP provisions are denaturant (natural gas condensate).  As of September 2009, Laddonia went to an inline blending process, so no denatured ethanol is stored on site.  The storage tank for denaturant (T-805) has overfill monitors and is located in a secondary containment area.  



Public access to the facility from the highway is restricted by a scalehouse.  Much of the property is fenced, limiting vehicle access.  Personnel are on-site 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.  There is a general alarm system at the facility and there is a multi-camera video surveillance system installed at the property.  The plant is fully lighted.  



Missouri Ethanol is committed to protection of the environment through the combined use of inspection, maintenance, employee training and response preparation.  All Missouri Ethanol employees receive basic chemical awareness and safety training.   In the event of an emergency, Missouri Ethanol's Emergency Coordinator will direct internal response activities to the extent they are within the qualifications and capabilities of company personnel, taking reasonable precautions to prevent or minimize the extent of release or the co-mingling of materials.  Employees within their designated work areas will respond to small releases, if such response does not pose a danger to their health or

safety, but there is no facility emergency response team.  Missouri Ethanol's Emergency Coordinator will determine if outside assistance is needed and access assistance through the Audrain County Joint Communication and 911 emergency dispatch and mutual aid service.  Missouri Ethanol's Emergency Coordinator will provide site logistics information to emergency responders; provide technical information to responders as to materials spilled (reactivity, control systems, etc.) and stored; and generally serve as technical information advisor to the Fire Department Incident Commander and/or contract hazardous material response team.  



Immediately after an emergency, Missouri Ethanol's Emergency Coordinator will provide for treating, storing, or disposing of recovered waste and contaminated materials in accordance with local, state and federal regulatory requirements.  The Emergency Coordinator will also assure that company-owned emergency response equipment is cleaned and/or restocked.



Missouri Ethanol's standard operating policy includes a goal of continuous safety improvement based on working experience and evaluation of procedures and technology.
